questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the composition of the external nose?

options.label: A
options.text: The external nose is entirely cartilaginous and contains only septal cartilage

options.label: B
options.text: The upper one-third of the external nose is bony, formed by the paired nasal bones

options.label: C
options.text: The lower one-third of the external nose is formed by nasal bones and vomer

options.label: D
options.text: The cartilaginous part includes only the upper lateral and alar cartilages

questions.correct_answer: B. The upper one-third of the external nose is bony, formed by the paired nasal bones
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The upper one-third of the external nose is bony, formed by the paired nasal bones

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The external nose is made up of an upper bony one-third (paired nasal bones) and a lower two-thirds cartilaginous part (including upper lateral, lower lateral/alar, lesser alar, and septal cartilages).
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 134

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with progressive thickening and enlargement of the tip of his nose over the past several years. He has a long-standing history of acne rosacea. On examination, his nasal tip appears bulbous, lobulated, and red with prominent pores. There are no signs of active infection or systemic symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rhinophyma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinophyma is a complication of acne rosacea caused by sebaceous gland hypertrophy, presenting as a bulbous, lobulated enlargement of the nasal tip, typically managed by laser or surgical excision.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 134
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 134

questions.text: A surgeon performing Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is evaluating the uncinate process attachment to determine the drainage pathway of the frontal sinus. options.text: Uncinate attached to lamina papyracea → Frontal sinus drains laterally into maxillary sinus

options.label: B
options.text: Uncinate attached to skull base → Frontal sinus drains medially into nasal cavity

options.label: C
options.text: Uncinate attached to middle turbinate → Frontal sinus drains laterally into infundibulum/maxillary sinus

options.label: D

Ans. C)
